webTitle: Standard Life jumps 5% as insurers lead FTSE 100 higher

fields.standfirst: Standard Life lifted by £390m Ignis deal while Legal & General boosted by ICI agreement
fields.body:
As leading shares move higher again, insurance companies are in the spotlight again.

Last Wednesday the sector was hit by the surprise news about annuities in the budget, but a week later the mood is more positive.

Standard Life has climbed 19.6p to 393.4p after it sealed a deal to pay £390m for Ignis Asset Management from Phoenix Holdings, up 29p to 739p. Analyst Eamonn Flanagan at Shore Capital said:

The addition of Ignis to Standard Life Investments means that third party funds under management now account for 64% of the total and 81% of revenue.
This purchase price is very much in the range that we expected and appears an attractive proposition for Standard Life as it moves comprehensively towards the asset accumulation/management model. However, such a deal does make it unlikely, in our view, that special dividends are likely to be on the cards in the short term. We reiterate our hold recommendation on Standard Life.

Berenberg analyst Matthew Preston said:

This transaction has merit for both parties, adding scale to Standard Life Investments, while facilitating Phoenix's debt-reduction plans;
The long-term strategic alliance between the two companies should also benefit both parties in the future in the event of further closed life consolidation activities at Phoenix.

Elsewhere Legal and General is up 5.8p to 215.3p following news of a £3bn annuity contract with the ICI pension fund. Eamonn Flanagan at Shore Capital again:

Legals has announced a bulk annuity deal with ICI covering £3bn of its liabilities, in the largest ever UK bulk purchase annuities deal.
In our view, this deal, with the remaining pipeline for such deals still strong, should allay any fears in the market over Legals' ability to deliver cash and growth following the changes to the individual annuity market announced in last week's budget. We reiterate our buy recommendation on Legals, seeing the recent stock sell-off as an excellent buying opportunity.

Just Retirement, up 6.7p at 143.2p, and Partnership, 5.7p better at 130.2p, were also hard hit after the budget and are now continuing to recover.

But RSA Insurance has fallen 7.3p to 87.9p as 1.38bn new shares were listed, nil paid, as part of its £773m rights issue.

Elsewhere Lloyds Banking Group has lost 3.15p to 75.96p following the UK government's sale of 5.6bn shares - a 7.8% stake - at 75.5p each.

A number of companies went ex-dividend including BSkyB, down 14.5p at 913p, and Schroders, 27p lower at £25.81.

Overall though, the FTSE 100 has continued Tuesday's gains by adding another 32.41 points to 6637.30. Talk of possible stimulus by the Chinese authorities to boost the country's flagging economy continued to help sentiment, as did dovish comments on Tuesday by various members of the European Central Bank. Positive US consumer confidence figures are also continuing to support the market. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

Investors put aside concerns about events in Russia and focussed on some fairly reasonable economic data, from Germany and the US, as well as the prospect of additional policy easing which drove strong gains across the board and into Asia this morning.
This move higher was given added impetus from two different directions starting with an expectation of some form of additional stimulus from Chinese authorities, and which came combined with a potentially significant softening of position from Jens Weidmann, President of the German Bundesbank, about the prospects of further policy easing by the ECB to counter a potential deflationary threat in the euro area.

fields.bodyText: The taxpayer's stake in Lloyds bank has been cut to 25%, after the government sold shares worth £4.2bn on Tuesday night. UK Financial Investments, the body that manages government shares in bailed-out banks Lloyds and Royal Bank of Scotland, said the government's holding had been cut to 24.9%, from 32.7%. George Osborne said the sale was good value for the taxpayer and that the money would be used to reduce the national debt. "This is another step in the government's long-term economic plan to deliver a more secure and resilient economy. It is another step in repairing the banks, in reducing our national debt and in getting the taxpayer's money back." It is the second sale in six months and suggests the bank could be back in full private ownership before the general election, in May 2015. The shares were sold at 75.5p each, a shade higher than the 73.6p the government paid at the height of the banking crisis when it injected £20bn into Lloyds. Royal Bank of Scotland was given a separate £45bn bailout. Half of the 5.6bn shares sold were bought by UK investors, 30% went to investors in the US, 10% to Asia and 10% to continental Europe, a source told Reuters. Shares in Lloyds fell 4.33% to 75.1p in early trading on Tuesday. The chief executive of Lloyds Banking Group, António Horta-Osório, last month declared that Lloyds was a normal bank as he was awarded a £1.7m bonus. On Monday, the bank revealed that its top management team would share bonuses worth more than £27m. UKFI and the Treasury have promised not to sell any further shares for the next 90 days without the consent of the City institutions that organised the sale.

webTitle: Government warned it may miss target for women in FTSE 100 boardrooms

fields.standfirst: Official data shows appointment of women to Britain's top boardrooms rising – but too slowly to meet the 25% target
fields.body:
The government has been warned it will miss its target of 25% female representation on boards of FTSE 100 companies by next year unless there is a boardroom hiring drive.

Official figures released on Wednesday show that while the appointment of women to Britain's top boardrooms is rising, progress is too slow to achieve the target set by Lord Davies of Abersoch in 2011.

Frances O'Grady, general secretary of the TUC, warned: "While progress is undoubtedly being made, the pace of change is too slow. And there are still companies with no female directors on their boards – at this rate it'll be decades before we see a 50/50 gender split at the top of British business."

O'Grady's comments came as Vince Cable's Department for Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) said women now account for 20.7% of board positions in the FTSE 100 – up from 12.5% in 2011 and 17.3% in April 2013.

If the rate of last year's rise in the number of female directors was repeated this year, it would leave the UK shy of Davies's 25% target in 12 months' time.

However, Cable expressed confidence that the target would be met, saying: "We need fewer than 50 new women appointments to FTSE 100 boards … in the next year."

He added: "We will only achieve this if there is a renewed, concentrated effort by chairs and chief executives to continue to change the make up of management at their top table."

BIS also hailed high-profile female executive appointments in the City over the past 12 months, including the recruitment of Inga Beale, Lloyd's of London's first female chief executive in its 325-year history.

The department added that women account for 33% of all board appointments in 2013/14, while there remain two all-male boards – mining groups Glencore Xstrata and Antofagasta.

The sluggish rate of increase in the rate of female directors in UK companies drew renewed criticism of how businesses operate. Ann Francke, chief executive of the Chartered Management Institute, added: "The real issue we need to confront is the lack of women in the talent pipeline. Too many talented women opt out before they fulfil their potential, because business culture puts them off – so we see, for example, from our data that only half as many men as women aim to reach chief executive. That's hardly any wonder when we still don't have enough female role models at the top of British businesses."

The performance by FTSE 250 companies lags behind the FTSE 100 list. According to BIS, there are 48 all-male boards on the list and female representation in boardrooms is running at 15.6%.

The BIS figures came as it was announced that more than 100 listed German companies will be required to allocate 30% of seats on their non-executive boards to women under planned new laws that were dismissed by critics as tokenism.

Although Europe's biggest economy has a female leader in chancellor Angela Merkel, women are under-represented in business life.

Among the 30 largest companies on Germany's blue-chip DAX index, women occupied about 22% of supervisory board seats and about 6% of executive board seats at the end of last year, according to the DIW economic thinktank.

Official figures released on Wednesday show that while the appointment of women to Britain's top boardrooms is rising, progress is too slow to achieve the target set by Lord Davies of Abersoch in 2011. Frances O'Grady, general secretary of the TUC, warned: "While progress is undoubtedly being made, the pace of change is too slow. And there are still companies with no female directors on their boards – at this rate it'll be decades before we see a 50/50 gender split at the top of British business." O'Grady's comments came as Vince Cable's Department for Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) said women now account for 20.7% of board positions in the FTSE 100 – up from 12.5% in 2011 and 17.3% in April 2013. If the rate of last year's rise in the number of female directors was repeated this year, it would leave the UK shy of Davies's 25% target in 12 months' time. However, Cable expressed confidence that the target would be met, saying: "We need fewer than 50 new women appointments to FTSE 100 boards … in the next year." He added: "We will only achieve this if there is a renewed, concentrated effort by chairs and chief executives to continue to change the make up of management at their top table." BIS also hailed high-profile female executive appointments in the City over the past 12 months, including the recruitment of Inga Beale, Lloyd's of London's first female chief executive in its 325-year history. The department added that women account for 33% of all board appointments in 2013/14, while there remain two all-male boards – mining groups Glencore Xstrata and Antofagasta. The sluggish rate of increase in the rate of female directors in UK companies drew renewed criticism of how businesses operate. Ann Francke, chief executive of the Chartered Management Institute, added: "The real issue we need to confront is the lack of women in the talent pipeline. Too many talented women opt out before they fulfil their potential, because business culture puts them off – so we see, for example, from our data that only half as many men as women aim to reach chief executive. That's hardly any wonder when we still don't have enough female role models at the top of British businesses." The performance by FTSE 250 companies lags behind the FTSE 100 list. According to BIS, there are 48 all-male boards on the list and female representation in boardrooms is running at 15.6%. The BIS figures came as it was announced that more than 100 listed German companies will be required to allocate 30% of seats on their non-executive boards to women under planned new laws that were dismissed by critics as tokenism. Although Europe's biggest economy has a female leader in chancellor Angela Merkel, women are under-represented in business life. Among the 30 largest companies on Germany's blue-chip DAX index, women occupied about 22% of supervisory board seats and about 6% of executive board seats at the end of last year, according to the DIW economic thinktank. fields.bodyText: Vince Cable will open a new front in the battle over boardroom pay on Wednesday with a warning to Britain's biggest companies that employees might be given a say over executive pay and perks if they fail to reform. In a speech to more than 30 FTSE 100 companies, the business secretary will say some remuneration committees are ignoring the spirit of a new law intended to improve transparency in the boardroom and link pay to performance. His intervention comes after a string of banks revealed lavish rewards for their top staff despite weak results. Barclays announced it would pay 481 employees £1m or more after a year when profits fell by a third and shareholders' dividends were flat; top managers at Lloyds will share £27m in bonuses even though the bank – 33% owned by the taxpayer – remains engulfed in mis-selling scandals. Cable is concerned that some companies are ignoring the spirit of sweeping reforms introduced in 2013 to promote transparency in the boardroom. Shareholders now have a binding vote on remuneration policy once every three years and companies must take into account the pay and conditions of the average employee when setting executive pay. "There is evidence that some remuneration committees have set about restoring a proper link between pay and performance in light of the government's reforms – with greater transparency and better engagement between companies and shareholders," Cable will tell his audience of FTSE listed companies - a rollcall of British businesses, including Marks & Spencer, easyJet and Investec. "But I have also heard some concerns that the improvements are far from universal, with some committees said to be observing the letter of the law but ignoring the spirit. "If companies and investors are unable or unwilling to act responsibly the pressure for stronger measures will be hard to ignore. Under such circumstances, I would consider options including stricter regulatory oversight of pay reports and policies, a requirement on shareholders to disclose how they have voted on pay, or a requirement to consult employees on pay." A government official said the details on consulting employees had not been worked out, saying: "It is a shot across the bows at this stage." British bosses now earn 133 times more than the average pay of their workforce, according to the High Pay Centre, and top pay has quadrupled in the last decade. The centre has warned that some companies are ignoring legal requirements to take the pay of ordinary workers into account when they set executive pay, and has called on the Financial Reporting Review Panel to intervene. "A cavalier attitude towards pay differentials and the regulations intended to contain them creates significant risk to employee morale in some of the UK's key companies and is harmful to trust in business more generally," the centre wrote last week in a letter to the regulator, which was also signed by investors such as the Local Authority Pension Fund Forum and Trade Union Share Owners. "It also widens the gap between the super-rich and everybody else to socially and economically destructive levels." But calls for further reform are set to cause alarm among some shareholder groups while annual reports revealing this year's pay are still at the printing presses. "Shareholders are currently waiting for an avalanche of annual reports to land in their inboxes. Only then can we judge if there have been material changes," said Sarah Wilson, chief executive of shareholder advisory group Manifest. "This proxy season is going to be immensely difficult for companies and shareholders and it is too early to prejudge the outcome [of the 2013 reforms]." Shareholders should not be expected to tackle social inequality, she said – "issues which are more appropriately looked at by government". "Shareholders' overriding responsibility, fiduciary responsibility, to savers is to ensure that companies perform well and provide good returns so savers can be rewarded." Wilson also voiced concern that mandatory voting disclosure could lead to "zombie voting" - blanket yes or no votes from shareholders seeking to avoid blame for backing or opposing a decision. "Voting is just one tool and sometimes it can be a blunt one. Sometimes a quiet conversation can achieve more."
